1123629254489587714.text: TCP expanded and evolved through a disparate collection of universities, corporations and individuals creating their own implementations, publishing them, and everyone seeing what works, eventually converging on the best one. (10/10)

1123629252753219584.text: OSI had been an attempt to create a worldwide communication standard by fiat, while TCP/IP, although in its origins, it did owe a lot to government-funded research networking standards, grew to become what it was by voluntary acceptance. (9/10)

1123629251050209281.text:
Instead, TCP/IP, one of the many university research networking standards available at the time, won out. By 1995, GOSIP was shut down as even OSI’s advocates acknowledged that TCP/IP had won. 

The reason why TCP/IP won was by the way that the two protocols were created. (8/10)

1123629249464815617.text: They proceeded to actively push it through policies called the Government OSI Profile, or GOSIP, which required computers purchased by the government to support this standard. However, OSI never caught on. (7/10)

1123629248462368770.text: There were many attempts to connect the networks together, including BITNET, UUCP and the corporate-controlled X.25. In 1980, governments around the world banded together to support the “Open Systems Interconnect” (OSI) group, which promoted a standard with the same name. (6/10)

1123629246738464769.text:
Two decades after ARPANET’s inception, the single government network had become a worldwide anarchy.

How was this conundrum resolved? (5/10)

1123629245014650881.text: Meanwhile, other network protocols underwent development, like UK’s National Physics Laboratory, Michigan’s Merit network, and the French CYCLADES. In the 80s, corporations entered the scene w/ proprietary networks of their own with no communications protocol between them. (4/10)

1123629243538333698.text: By 1972, however, the number of clients connected had increased to 37, and people began to realize that they had created something which might be useful for more than just distributed computing and the military. (3/10)

1123629242158333952.text:
The concept had its humble beginnings in ARPANET, a decentralized network created by the US military’s Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) in the 60s.

ARPANET first went live in 1969, connecting a mere four terminals at 4 universities in California and Utah. (2/10)
